{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3139939,"name":"","username":"iz_en_zi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/iz_en_zi/{size}/226207_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-05T07:15:41.955Z","cooked":"

Hi, this is our team’s first year using pneumatics on our robot since 2016. We were able to fully get the pneumatic system on our robot to work with the same code that we are using now on our robot before we rewired it to make it neater. However, after we went to test it, the PH is no longer enabling the compressor. This is a link to our github and this is the code used to make the compressor run:

Screenshot 2023-02-05 at 1.02.43 AM1658×278 41.4 KB

We believed the code to be correct, so we then started looking for wiring errors. Our first troubleshooting step we took was to follow the instructions on Rev’s website and enter test mode. In test mode, the compressor enabled fine. We then checked the overall pressure gauge, but that was not the problem either. Unless we are missing something (which, we probably are), this leaves only the CAN loop to be investigated. By some parts, this makes sense, as, towards the end of troubleshooting, we began to receive this error (apologies for it not being a screenshot):

Screenshot 2023-02-05 at 1.10.36 AM868×752 89.8 KB

The only issue with the theory of it being a CAN error is that the PH is the first item in our CAN loop, plugged in directly to the RoboRio, and the rest of the motor controllers were receiving data and actuating. From my understanding of CAN, if the first item in the loop goes down, everything else goes down with it. If that were the case and it is a CAN error, why would the rest of the items on the loop receive proper data? Is there something we are missing? Besides checking the CAN loop, what troubleshooting steps should we take next? Thank You!

– Ian, Team 3926

docs.revrobotics.com

Pneumatic Hub Firmware Changelog

Looks like the latest (23.0.1) fixes a similar issue IF youre not setting the mode explicitly (which you are by calling enableDigital()). Just for the record though, you shouldnt need to do that. I believe thats the default configuration, which would apply as soon as you instantiate a Solenoid or DoubleSolenoid object.

If the mode button “test mode” works, and the Hardware Client works, then I can only assume its something in your code, though I’m not sure what

Pneumatic Hub","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48541,"username":"iz_en_zi","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/iz_en_zi/{size}/226207_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/rev-ph-not-turning-on-compressor-when-code-previously-worked-and-can-loop-is-functional/425829/5","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3139946,"name":"","username":"iz_en_zi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/iz_en_zi/{size}/226207_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-05T07:34:20.389Z","cooked":"

I would want to assume it’s a code issue as well, but the issue is it is the exact same code we had working on Thursday night without anything in it having changed. The test mode working narrows the issue down to the CANbus but the CANbus is allowing devices further in the bus to work. From some tests (although i’m not 100% certain) it looks like it may be outputting data fine but not receiving it properly. Is this something that could happen? The rest of the loop is sending/receiving fine.

Have you connected directly to the PH with the Rev Hardware Client and checked for device faults and the statuses?
You can connect to one of your other Rev devices like a Spark Max to see if the PH appears on the CAN bus device list.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-02-05T14:27:17.407Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":111,"readers_count":110,"score":42.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":425829,"topic_slug":"rev-ph-not-turning-on-compressor-when-code-previously-worked-and-can-loop-is-functional","display_username":"Mark McLeod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48541,"username":"iz_en_zi","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/iz_en_zi/{size}/226207_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2123,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Itinerant Troubleshooter"},"post_url":"/t/rev-ph-not-turning-on-compressor-when-code-previously-worked-and-can-loop-is-functional/425829/7","custom_user_title":"Itinerant Troubleshooter","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3140002,"name":null,"username":"ksquare","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ksquare/{size}/121038_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-05T14:28:45.021Z","cooked":"

Does your code contain a reference to at least one solenoid? What tripped me off in the past was that the automated on/off control of the compressor only worked when there was also at least one solenoid. That was with the CTRE pneumatics controller, not REV, but maybe the same idea is implemented in the REV PH support: No solenoid → compressor always kept off?

yep, we were able to connect to it from the pdh

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-02-05T14:54:50.208Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":96,"readers_count":95,"score":29.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":425829,"topic_slug":"rev-ph-not-turning-on-compressor-when-code-previously-worked-and-can-loop-is-functional","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":2123,"username":"Mark_McLeod","name":"Mark McLeod","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mark_mcleod/{size}/65145_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"now a sad alumni"},"post_url":"/t/rev-ph-not-turning-on-compressor-when-code-previously-worked-and-can-loop-is-functional/425829/9","custom_user_title":"now a sad alumni","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3140015,"name":"","username":"iz_en_zi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/iz_en_zi/{size}/226207_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-05T14:56:17.293Z","cooked":"

the solenoids are in the subsystem of the code. We also tried our code from PneumaticsTest, where everything is done in the SolenoidSubsystem

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-02-05T14:56:17.293Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":95,"readers_count":94,"score":19.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":425829,"topic_slug":"rev-ph-not-turning-on-compressor-when-code-previously-worked-and-can-loop-is-functional","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":38843,"username":"ksquare","name":null,"avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ksquare/{size}/121038_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"now a sad alumni"},"post_url":"/t/rev-ph-not-turning-on-compressor-when-code-previously-worked-and-can-loop-is-functional/425829/10","custom_user_title":"now a sad alumni","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3140032,"name":"dyanoshak","username":"dyanoshak","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dyanoshak/{size}/65422_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-05T15:27:22.299Z","cooked":"
iz_en_zi:

The only issue with the theory of it being a CAN error is that the PH is the first item in our CAN loop, plugged in directly to the RoboRio, and the rest of the motor controllers were receiving data and actuating. From my understanding of CAN, if the first item in the loop goes down, everything else goes down with it. If that were the case and it is a CAN error, why would the rest of the items on the loop receive proper data?

iz_en_zi:

The test mode working narrows the issue down to the CANbus but the CANbus is allowing devices further in the bus to work. From some tests (although i’m not 100% certain) it looks like it may be outputting data fine but not receiving it properly. Is this something that could happen? The rest of the loop is sending/receiving fine.

Each module has a direct physical connection between the two CANH and CANL terminals. Therefore, unless the module is so damaged that it shorts the bus, or the wires have disconnected from the module, CAN traffic will get to the other devices as you’re describing regardless if the module in question is having its own issue.

It is definitely possible to have flipped polarity on your CAN wiring in two places. That would prevent any module between those two flips from communicating, while others will still work.

I would go through and double check the entire CAN network wiring in extreme detail as a first step.

iz_en_zi:

yep, we were able to connect to it from the pdh

The fact that you saw the PH in the Hardware Client on the network while connected to the PDH via USB implies that at least the CAN connection between the two is OK, but still go over the entire bus. Also, to isolate variables, connect to the PH’s USB port directly, instead of the PDH, and check for any faults.

iz_en_zi:

We are on the latest PH release (we checked if it was updated like 3 times haha)

Not to sound pedantic, but go back and verify your PH is specifically on version 23.0.1. It is possible that if you’re checking for updates on a school network, firewalls or proxies will prevent the latest updates from loading.

I think we should be able to try the first one and make sure everything on the CAN is connected properly.

We’ve also been able to connect to it directly through the PH (I think we’re actually connected to it in the photo above), and the PH is running 2023.0.1.

Thanks for helping out!

Would the side of the PH Can terminals affect anything (i.e. the input being on the left two terminals and the output being on the right)? From what I’ve been told it shouldn’t make a difference but that could be causing the problem?

We checked all of the CAN wiring, and it seems that the PH is getting the correct signals to actuate the solenoids. The only thing that is not enabling is the Compressor.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-02-06T22:06:04.402Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":45,"readers_count":44,"score":19.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":425829,"topic_slug":"rev-ph-not-turning-on-compressor-when-code-previously-worked-and-can-loop-is-functional","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":9020,"username":"dyanoshak","name":"dyanoshak","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dyanoshak/{size}/65422_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"now a sad alumni"},"post_url":"/t/rev-ph-not-turning-on-compressor-when-code-previously-worked-and-can-loop-is-functional/425829/17","custom_user_title":"now a sad alumni","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3140936,"name":"Al Skierkiewicz Learn Something New, Every Day!","username":"Al_Skierkiewicz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/al_skierkiewicz/{size}/110877_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-06T22:32:07.752Z","cooked":"

If you can start the compressor with the mode button, then I can assume you can also start it from the dashboard app connected through USB port. That only leaves code and the pressure switch. Be sure that if you are using a switch, that it be connected to the “digital pressure switch” port. If you are using the analog pressure transducer, it must be connected to the “analog pressure sensor” port. Does the LED next to the compressor port turn on when the robot is enabled? You can substitute a short jumper for the digital pressure switch connected to the terminals of the PH. If you are using the digital switch in code, then the compressor should start when the robot is enabled.

We found the issue: The 120psi regulator switches did not pass a continuity test. We swapped out those wires and now have a working compressor.
